fast3d.graphics

Class Graphics3d

  • java.lang.Object
    • fast3d.graphics.Graphics3d
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Turtle3d

    public class Graphics3d
extends java.lang.Object
    with a graphics3d you can draw directly onto a regular 2d-screen but in 3d
    Author:
    Tim Trense

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Graphics3d(java.awt.Graphics2D g, Shader sh, Light... lights)
      constructs a graphics3d-wrapper around a 2d-graphics-context with a shader to convert 3d in 2d

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void drawString(java.lang.String text, Vector3d pos)
      shades the given vertex and uses the pixel to determine where to draw a 2d-string on the screen
      works just fine for call-outs, remember the text will be not 3d
      boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)
      compares this with the parameter and returns false if the parameter is not of the same type
      java.awt.Graphics2D getGraphics2d() 
      Shader getShader()
      it is highly recommended to not access the shader directly
      you may get some camera-information out of it but changing the internal data will probably crash the render-process
      Color illuminateSurface(Illuminatable illum)
      does the lighting calculation for any used light and combines them to the visible color for the given surface
      static Color illuminateSurface(Illuminatable illum, Light... lights)
      does the lighting calculation for any given light and combines them to the visible color for the given surface
      void line(Vector3d start, Vector3d end)
      shades the vertices and draws a line from one of these pixels to the other
      works like drawing a 3d-line
      void pixel(Vector3d pos)
      shades the given vertex and sets the pixel to the previous set color by setColor(Color)
      works like drawing a 3d-pixel
      void pixel(Vector3d pos, int width)
      shades the given vertex and sets the pixel to the previous set color by setColor(Color)
      works like drawing a 3d-pixel
      void polygon(Vector3d... ps)
      shades all vertices using shadeAll() and draws a polygon over these pixels (filled if wireFrameMode is false)
      works like drawing a 3d-polygon (should be not too big in complex sceneries) if wireframeMode is on(true), a polygon is just a polyline where the first and last point are equal
      void polyline(Vector3d... ps)
      shades all vertices using shadeAll() and draws a polyline over these
      works like drawing a 3d-polyline (should be not too big in complex sceneries)
      if wireframeMode is on(true), a polygon is just a polyline where the first and last point are equal
      void setColor(Color col)
      converts the given color to the corresponding one from awt and sets the backing graphics2D to that
      void setFont(java.awt.Font font)
      sets the font for the contained 2d-graphics
      equal to getGraphics2d().setFont(Font)
      Vector2d shade(Vector3d v)
      converts one given vertex in pixel-coordinates
      faster than getShader().shade(vertices) because of buffering-features
      if a vertex is shaded to null according to the camera-mode-settings, this method will return null too
      java.util.List<Vector2d> shadeAll(Vector3d... vecs)
      converts all given vertices in pixel-coordinates
      faster than getShader().shade(vertices) because of buffering-features
      if a vertex is shaded to null according to the camera-mode-settings, it won't be added to the return-list
      void sort(java.util.Map<Vector3d,RenderAction> call)
      sorts the given keys in relation to their position to the camera and then calls the run method for the corresponding value so it can draw something
      void sort(Renderable... r)
      sorts the given array very fast but correct to draw the renderables then in the order of the array, so that they will hide each other in the perspectively correct order
      the nearest to the camera renderable will be at the last index of the array, the most far one at first
      java.lang.String toString() 

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, wait, wait, wait

    • Constructor Detail

      • Graphics3d

        public Graphics3d(java.awt.Graphics2D g,
                  Shader sh,
                  Light... lights)
        constructs a graphics3d-wrapper around a 2d-graphics-context with a shader to convert 3d in 2d
        Parameters:
        g - the 2d-graphics context to draw on
        sh - the 3d/2d-converter
        lights - all used lights to illuminate the scenery

    • Method Detail

      • equals

        public boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)
        compares this with the parameter and returns false if the parameter is not of the same type
        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        whether this and the given Graphics3d are equal considering their wireFrameMode-state, backing Graphics2D, backing Shader, used lights and frameID

      • getShader

        public Shader getShader()
        it is highly recommended to not access the shader directly
        you may get some camera-information out of it but changing the internal data will probably crash the render-process
        Returns:
        the shader

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        fast3d.graphics.Graphics3d[_parameter_]

      • shadeAll

        public java.util.List<Vector2d> shadeAll(Vector3d... vecs)
        converts all given vertices in pixel-coordinates
        faster than getShader().shade(vertices) because of buffering-features
        if a vertex is shaded to null according to the camera-mode-settings, it won't be added to the return-list
        Parameters:
        vecs - all vertices to shade
        Returns:
        all not-null shaded pixel coordinates of the vertices

      • shade

        public Vector2d shade(Vector3d v)
        converts one given vertex in pixel-coordinates
        faster than getShader().shade(vertices) because of buffering-features
        if a vertex is shaded to null according to the camera-mode-settings, this method will return null too
        Parameters:
        v - the vertex to shade
        Returns:
        its corresponding pixel-coordinates according to the current camera setting

      • setColor

        public void setColor(Color col)
        converts the given color to the corresponding one from awt and sets the backing graphics2D to that
        Parameters:
        col - the color to draw in

      • pixel

        public void pixel(Vector3d pos)
        shades the given vertex and sets the pixel to the previous set color by setColor(Color)
        works like drawing a 3d-pixel
        Parameters:
        pos - the vertex to color

      • pixel

        public void pixel(Vector3d pos,
                  int width)
        shades the given vertex and sets the pixel to the previous set color by setColor(Color)
        works like drawing a 3d-pixel
        Parameters:
        pos - the vertex to color
        width - the size of the pixel

      • line

        public void line(Vector3d start,
                 Vector3d end)
        shades the vertices and draws a line from one of these pixels to the other
        works like drawing a 3d-line
        Parameters:
        start - one of the two vertices
        end - the other vertex

      • polygon

        public void polygon(Vector3d... ps)
        shades all vertices using shadeAll() and draws a polygon over these pixels (filled if wireFrameMode is false)
        works like drawing a 3d-polygon (should be not too big in complex sceneries) if wireframeMode is on(true), a polygon is just a polyline where the first and last point are equal
        Parameters:
        ps - the edges of the polygon
        See Also:
        polyline(Vector3d...)

      • polyline

        public void polyline(Vector3d... ps)
        shades all vertices using shadeAll() and draws a polyline over these
        works like drawing a 3d-polyline (should be not too big in complex sceneries)
        if wireframeMode is on(true), a polygon is just a polyline where the first and last point are equal
        Parameters:
        ps - the points of the line
        See Also:
        polygon(Vector3d...)

      • sort

        public void sort(Renderable... r)
        sorts the given array very fast but correct to draw the renderables then in the order of the array, so that they will hide each other in the perspectively correct order
        the nearest to the camera renderable will be at the last index of the array, the most far one at first
        Parameters:
        r - the scenery to be calculated

      • sort

        public void sort(java.util.Map<Vector3d,RenderAction> call)
        sorts the given keys in relation to their position to the camera and then calls the run method for the corresponding value so it can draw something
        Parameters:
        call - a mapping of where to render what

      • drawString

        public void drawString(java.lang.String text,
                       Vector3d pos)
        shades the given vertex and uses the pixel to determine where to draw a 2d-string on the screen
        works just fine for call-outs, remember the text will be not 3d
        Parameters:
        text - the string to draw
        pos - the vertex determining the screen pixel-position where to draw

      • illuminateSurface

        public Color illuminateSurface(Illuminatable illum)
        does the lighting calculation for any used light and combines them to the visible color for the given surface
        Parameters:
        illum - the surface to do the lighting-calculation for
        Returns:
        the visible color of the surface in the current scenery-setting

      • illuminateSurface

        public static Color illuminateSurface(Illuminatable illum,
                                      Light... lights)
        does the lighting calculation for any given light and combines them to the visible color for the given surface
        Parameters:
        illum - the surface to do the lighting-calculation for
        lights - the lights effecting the surface
        Returns:
        the visible color of the surface in the current scenery-setting

      • getGraphics2d

        public java.awt.Graphics2D getGraphics2d()
        Returns:
        the backing 2d-awt-graphics-context as a reference to draw in 2d over the scenery

      • setFont

        public void setFont(java.awt.Font font)
        sets the font for the contained 2d-graphics
        equal to getGraphics2d().setFont(Font)
        Parameters:
        font - the font to set
